On Bus Graph Realizability††thanks: Our interest in bus graph problems is a consequence of the participation of one of us in Bertinoro Workshop on Graph Drawing, 5–10 March, 2006 where the problem was presented as an open problem. Contact author: Ethan Kim, School of Computer Science, McGill University, 3480 University St., Montréal, Canada, ethan@cs.mcgill.ca

Anil Ada    Melanie Coggan    Paul Di Marco    Alain Doyon    Liam Flookes    Samuli Heilala    Ethan Kim    Jonathan Li On Wing    Louis-Francois Preville-Ratelle    Sue Whitesides    Nuo Yu
Abstract

In this paper, we consider the following graph embedding problem: Given a bipartite graph G=(V1,V2;E)𝐺subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2𝐸G=(V_{1},V_{2};E)italic_G = ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_E ), where the maximum degree of vertices in V2subscript𝑉2V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 4, can G𝐺Gitalic_G be embedded on a two dimensional grid such that each vertex in V1subscript𝑉1V_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a line segment along a grid line, each vertex in V2subscript𝑉2V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a point at a grid point, and each edge e=(u,v)𝑒𝑢𝑣e=(u,v)italic_e = ( italic_u , italic_v ) for some u∈V1𝑢subscript𝑉1u\in V_{1}italic_u ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v∈V2𝑣subscript𝑉2v\in V_{2}italic_v ∈ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn as a line segment connecting u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, perpendicular to the line segment for u𝑢uitalic_u? We show that this problem is NP-complete, and sketch how our proof techniques can be used to show the hardness of several other related problems.

Technical Report SOCS-TR-2006.1, September 2006

1 Introduction

Orthogonal graph drawing is a well studied area in the graph drawing community, and one may find many applications in VLSI design. In this paper, we study orthogonal drawings of bus graphs, which represent interconnectivity of functional entities in a chip. In VLSI layouts, a bus is a line segment drawn on a plane. To establish a connection among a collection of buses, a connector is drawn as a point on the plane, and then joined to the buses by line segments. Thus, the interconnections of the buses can be represented by a bipartite graph, where one partition of vertices corresponds to the set of buses, and the other corresponds to the set of connectors. We call such bipartite graphs bus graphs, and we are interested in the problem of drawing bus graphs on the plane.

For manufacturing purposes, it is desired that all the buses and the edges that join them are laid out either horizontally or vertically. Furthermore, it is also necessary to lay out the components of a chip, i.e. buses and connectors, sufficiently far from each other. Thus, we wish to draw the bus graph on a grid, where each bus is laid out along a grid line, and each connector is drawn at a grid point. Each edge between a bus and a connector is also drawn along a grid line. In particular, an edge joining a bus is drawn as a line segment perpendicular to the bus. We do not allow any edge to intersect with any connectors or buses, except at endpoints of the edge. However, a horizontal edge may cross a vertical edge. Thus, each connector can connect at most 4 buses. We define the combinatorial bus graphs as the class of bipartite graphs G=(ℬ,𝒞;ℰ)𝐺ℬ𝒞ℰG=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ), where the degree of connector vertices in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is at most 4.

We say a (combinatorial) bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is realizable if G𝐺Gitalic_G can be drawn while meeting the conditions above. See Fig. 1 for an example of a bus graph and its realization. We now formally define the Bus Graph Realizability (BGR) problem as follows:

Instance: A bipartite graph G=(ℬ,𝒞;ℰ)𝐺ℬ𝒞ℰG=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) such that ∀c∈𝒞for-all𝑐𝒞\forall c\in\mathcal{C}∀ italic_c ∈ caligraphic_C, deg⁡(c)≤4degree𝑐4\deg(c)\leq 4roman_deg ( italic_c ) ≤ 4.

Question: Can G𝐺Gitalic_G be drawn onto a grid so that the following properties hold?

  1. 1.

    Each vertex B∈ℬ𝐵ℬB\in\mathcal{B}italic_B ∈ caligraphic_B is drawn as a closed line segment along a grid line.

  2. 2.

    Each vertex c∈𝒞𝑐𝒞c\in\mathcal{C}italic_c ∈ caligraphic_C is drawn as a point at a grid point.

  3. 3.

    Each edge (B,c)∈ℰ𝐵𝑐ℰ(B,c)\in\mathcal{E}( italic_B , italic_c ) ∈ caligraphic_E is drawn as a closed line segment between B𝐵Bitalic_B and c𝑐citalic_c, that is perpendicular to B𝐵Bitalic_B, and contains no other connectors or buses apart from B𝐵Bitalic_B and c𝑐citalic_c; an edge can, however, cross other edges as shown in Fig. 1. An edge may connect to a bus at an endpoint of the bus.

  4. 4.

    No buses or connectors may intersect.

Now we are ready to state our main result.

Theorem 1.1

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2, we give definitions and preliminaries. A proof of our main theorem is given in Sect. 3. In Sect. 4, we show that the techniques we use to prove Theorem 1.1 can be applied to related problems. In Sect. 5, we look at a variation of the problem where the lengths of the buses are given as input, and prove that this version of the problem is NP-hard. Finally, we conclude with some open problems in Sect. 6.

1.0.1 Related Work.

The orthogonal graph drawing style has found many applications in VLSI design since its introduction in [1], [2], and [3]. Many optimization criteria have been suggested, such as minimizing layout area, minimizing the number of wire crossings in a layout, etc. ([4], [5])

A realization of a bus graph conveys visibility relations among the buses and connectors. Given an arrangement of points (connectors) and axis-parallel line segments (buses) on a grid, if a bus Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a connector cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be joined by a straight-line edge, then there exists an axis-parallel line of sight that does not intersect any buses or connectors except Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, if all the buses are drawn horizontally, the bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is a subgraph of the visibility graph representing the vertical visibility among the bus segments. There is an abundance of prior work on the visibility graphs based on axis-parallel lines of sight, for example, in [6], [7], [8], [9], [10], [11], [12], and [13]. In particular, [10] and [11] study bar visibility graphs (BVGs), where each vertex in the graph is drawn as a horizontal line segment in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\bbbr^{2}roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the adjacency among the vertices represent vertical visibility. It is shown that the recognition problem of such graphs can be solved in linear time. In [7], [9], [8], [12], [13], the authors study rectangle visibility graphs (RVGs), where each vertex is drawn as a rectangle, and the adjacency among the vertices represent axis-parallel lines of sight. Reference [13] shows that the recognition problem of such graphs is NP-complete. The bus graphs that we study in this paper can be regarded as related to RVGs, where the vertices are restricted to degenerate rectangles such as line segments and points.

2 Preliminaries

Given a bus graph G=(ℬ,𝒞;ℰ)𝐺ℬ𝒞ℰG=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ), we call a vertex B𝐵Bitalic_B a ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex if B∈ℬ𝐵ℬB\in\mathcal{B}italic_B ∈ caligraphic_B; its realization is called a bus. Similarly, a 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex refers to a vertex in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, and its realization is called a connector. We often use uppercase letters to denote ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, and lowercase letters to denote 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices.

We use a function ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ to denote an embedding of a combinatorial bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G. For example, Γ⁢(c)Γ𝑐\Gamma(c)roman_Γ ( italic_c ) for some 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex c𝑐citalic_c denotes the grid point where c𝑐citalic_c is laid out in the embedding, and Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) for some ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex B𝐵Bitalic_B or Γ⁢((B,c))Γ𝐵𝑐\Gamma((B,c))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B , italic_c ) ) for some edge (B,c)𝐵𝑐(B,c)( italic_B , italic_c ) denotes the line segment along a grid line where the bus or edge is laid out. We call a grid point an event point if there is either a connector or an endpoint of a bus at that grid point.

It is important to note here that many variations of the bus graph problem can be devised, yet several are equivalent. For example, suppose the buses are realized as open line segments. It is not hard to see that this variation is equivalent to the problem stated in Sect. 1, as an embedding with buses as open line segments can easily be transformed into an embedding with buses as closed line segments, and vice versa.

For another variation, note that a bus graph G=(ℬ,𝒞;ℰ)𝐺ℬ𝒞ℰG=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) can be regarded as a hypergraph, where ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B is the set of vertices, and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is the set of hyperedges, each connecting at most four vertices. In this context, it is of interest to see if the realizability problem changes if we disallow multiple hyperedges in the hypergraph G𝐺Gitalic_G. In other words, we would assume that no two 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices are adjacent to the same set of ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. As the following lemma shows, this assumption does not change our problem.

Lemma 1

Let G𝐺Gitalic_G be a bus graph with multiple hyperedges in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C, and let G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the bus graph constructed from G𝐺Gitalic_G by removing hyperedge duplicates. Then G𝐺Gitalic_G is realizable if and only if G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is realizable.

Proof

Necessity is trivial. Conversely, suppose G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is realizable. Take any embedding of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let c𝑐citalic_c be a connector in the embedding at some position (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j)( italic_i , italic_j ). Then, create a copy of c𝑐citalic_c with the same connectivity to buses as follows. For each event point in the embedding, if its x𝑥xitalic_x-coordinate is strictly greater than i𝑖iitalic_i, increase its x𝑥xitalic_x-coordinate by 1. Then, if c𝑐citalic_c is connected to the rightmost endpoint of a horizontal bus B𝐵Bitalic_B, where the endpoint is at an x𝑥xitalic_x-coordinate equal to i𝑖iitalic_i, increase the x𝑥xitalic_x-coordinate of the endpoint by 1. Similarly, if an event point has a y𝑦yitalic_y-coordinate strictly greater than j𝑗jitalic_j, increase its y𝑦yitalic_y-coordinate by 1. Then, if c𝑐citalic_c is connected to the topmost endpoint of a vertical bus B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where the endpoint is at a y𝑦yitalic_y-coordinate equal to j𝑗jitalic_j, increase the y𝑦yitalic_y-coordinate of the endpoint by 1. Finally, create a copy of c𝑐citalic_c, and place it at (i+1,j+1)𝑖1𝑗1(i+1,j+1)( italic_i + 1 , italic_j + 1 ). Intuitively, we are stretching the buses that intersect either of the two grid lines x=i𝑥𝑖x=iitalic_x = italic_i and y=j𝑦𝑗y=jitalic_y = italic_j, so that there is a grid point for the newly created copy of c𝑐citalic_c, without making any collisions. Repeat this for each 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, until a realization of G𝐺Gitalic_G is obtained. ∎

3 NP-Completeness

3.1 Membership in NP

Lemma 2

Bus graph realizability is in NP.

Proof

First, we claim that if a bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is realizable, there exists a compact layout such that the size of the layout is linear in each dimension. To see this, take any layout of G𝐺Gitalic_G, and compact the layout as follows. Take a vertical grid line with no event points on it. Then, for each event point at (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) appearing to the right of this grid line, shift it to (x−1,y)𝑥1𝑦(x-1,y)( italic_x - 1 , italic_y ). Observe that this operation still guarantees a legal layout. Repeat this for each such vertical grid line. Notice that the width of the layout is now linear in the size of G𝐺Gitalic_G. We can apply a similar operation for all such horizontal grid lines. Thus, the claim is true, so there exists a short certificate for each realizable graph G𝐺Gitalic_G that gives the coordinates of the event points in a compact layout. It is easy to see that we can check, in polynomial time, if such a certificate represents a correct solution.∎

3.2 NP-Hardness

In this section, we prove the NP-hardness of BGR by a reduction from NAE-3SAT [14]. We first introduce and discuss properties of several gadgets, and then give the transformation.

Definition 1

An (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp is a bus graph component consisting of three 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices x𝑥xitalic_x, y𝑦yitalic_y, z𝑧zitalic_z, five ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices A𝐴Aitalic_A, A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, B𝐵Bitalic_B, B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, C𝐶Citalic_C, and twelve edges (A,x)𝐴𝑥(A,x)( italic_A , italic_x ), (A′,x)superscript𝐴′𝑥(A^{\prime},x)( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x ), (B,x)𝐵𝑥(B,x)( italic_B , italic_x ), (B′,x)superscript𝐵′𝑥(B^{\prime},x)( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x ), (A,y)𝐴𝑦(A,y)( italic_A , italic_y ), (A′,y)superscript𝐴′𝑦(A^{\prime},y)( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y ), (B,y)𝐵𝑦(B,y)( italic_B , italic_y ), (C,y)𝐶𝑦(C,y)( italic_C , italic_y ), (A,z)𝐴𝑧(A,z)( italic_A , italic_z ), (A′,z)superscript𝐴′𝑧(A^{\prime},z)( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ), (B′,z)superscript𝐵′𝑧(B^{\prime},z)( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ), (C,z)𝐶𝑧(C,z)( italic_C , italic_z ).

A combinatorial graph of an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp and an example embedding of it are shown in Fig. 1.

Lemma 3

In any embedding Γnormal-Γ\Gammaroman_Γ of an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp,

  1. 1.

    Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) and Γ⁢(B′)Γsuperscript𝐵′\Gamma(B^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are parallel,

  2. 2.

    Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ) and Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) are perpendicular, and

  3. 3.

    Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ) and Γ⁢(A′)Γsuperscript𝐴′\Gamma(A^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are parallel.

Proof

  1. 1.

    Note that y𝑦yitalic_y and z𝑧zitalic_z are both adjacent to A𝐴Aitalic_A, A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and C𝐶Citalic_C. Γ⁢((B,y))Γ𝐵𝑦\Gamma((B,y))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B , italic_y ) ) and Γ⁢((B′,z))Γsuperscript𝐵′𝑧\Gamma((B^{\prime},z))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ) ) are then parallel, so Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) and Γ⁢(B′)Γsuperscript𝐵′\Gamma(B^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are parallel.

  2. 2.

    By 1, Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) and Γ⁢(B′)Γsuperscript𝐵′\Gamma(B^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are parallel. So if Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ) were parallel to Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ), then x𝑥xitalic_x would be adjacent to three parallel buses. This is a contradiction.

  3. 3.

    By 2, Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ) and Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) are perpendicular. If Γ⁢(A′)Γsuperscript𝐴′\Gamma(A^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) were perpendicular to Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ), then Γ⁢(A′)Γsuperscript𝐴′\Gamma(A^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) would be parallel to Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ), making x𝑥xitalic_x adjacent to three parallel buses. This is a contradiction.

∎

Definition 2

A (B,o)𝐵𝑜(B,o)( italic_B , italic_o )-flipper is a bus graph component consisting of an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp, one additional 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex o𝑜oitalic_o, and two additional edges (B,o)𝐵𝑜(B,o)( italic_B , italic_o ), (B′,o)superscript𝐵′𝑜(B^{\prime},o)( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_o ).

An example embedding of a (B,o)𝐵𝑜(B,o)( italic_B , italic_o )-flipper is shown in Fig. 3.

Lemma 4

Let i𝑖iitalic_i be a 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex, and O𝑂Oitalic_O be a ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex.   1. 1.

    Γ⁢((B,i))Γ𝐵𝑖\Gamma((B,i))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B , italic_i ) ) and Γ⁢((O,o))Γ𝑂𝑜\Gamma((O,o))roman_Γ ( ( italic_O , italic_o ) ) are perpendicular, and

  2. 2.

    Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) and Γ⁢(O)Γ𝑂\Gamma(O)roman_Γ ( italic_O ) are perpendicular.

  1. 1.

    By Lemma 3, Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) and Γ⁢(B′)Γsuperscript𝐵′\Gamma(B^{\prime})roman_Γ ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are parallel, so Γ⁢((B,o))Γ𝐵𝑜\Gamma((B,o))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B , italic_o ) ) and Γ⁢((B′,o))Γsuperscript𝐵′𝑜\Gamma((B^{\prime},o))roman_Γ ( ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_o ) ) are also parallel.   2. 2.

    Follows immediately from 1.

∎

An (A,k,B,l)𝐴𝑘𝐵𝑙(A,k,B,l)( italic_A , italic_k , italic_B , italic_l )-variable-box is a bus graph component consisting of an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp, (3+k)+(3+l)3𝑘3𝑙(3+k)+(3+l)( 3 + Lemma 5

Let (OAi,oAi)subscriptsuperscript𝑂𝑖𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑖𝐴(O^{i}_{A},o^{i}_{A})( italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for i=1,2,…,k𝑖12normal-…𝑘i=1,2,\ldots,kitalic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_k and (OBj,oBj)subscriptsuperscript𝑂𝑗𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑗𝐵(O^{j}_{B},o^{j}_{B})( italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for j=1,2,…,l𝑗12normal-…𝑙j=1,2,\ldots,litalic_j = 1 , 2 , … , italic_l be edges joined with an (A,k,B,l)𝐴𝑘𝐵𝑙(A,k,B,l)( italic_A , italic_k , italic_B , italic_l )-variable-box. Then in any embedding Γnormal-Γ\Gammaroman_Γ,

  1. 1.

    Γ⁢((OAi,oAi))Γsubscriptsuperscript𝑂𝑖𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑖𝐴\Gamma((O^{i}_{A},o^{i}_{A}))roman_Γ ( ( italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) and Γ⁢(A)Γ𝐴\Gamma(A)roman_Γ ( italic_A ) are perpendicular for any i=1,2,…,k𝑖12…𝑘i=1,2,\ldots,kitalic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_k.

  2. 2.

    Γ⁢((OBi,oBi))Γsubscriptsuperscript𝑂𝑖𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑖𝐵\Gamma((O^{i}_{B},o^{i}_{B}))roman_Γ ( ( italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) and Γ⁢(B)Γ𝐵\Gamma(B)roman_Γ ( italic_B ) are perpendicular for any i=1,2,…,l𝑖12…𝑙i=1,2,\ldots,litalic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_l.

Proof

We prove the first statement; the proof of the second is analogous. Notice that vertices xAsubscript𝑥𝐴x_{A}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yAsubscript𝑦𝐴y_{A}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, zAsubscript𝑧𝐴z_{A}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, RAsubscript𝑅𝐴R_{A}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, SAsubscript𝑆𝐴S_{A}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, TAsubscript𝑇𝐴T_{A}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, UAsubscript𝑈𝐴U_{A}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, oA1subscriptsuperscript𝑜1𝐴o^{1}_{A}italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, oA2subscriptsuperscript𝑜2𝐴o^{2}_{A}italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, …, oAksubscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑘𝐴o^{k}_{A}italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT form an (RA,oAi)subscript𝑅𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑖𝐴(R_{A},o^{i}_{A})( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-flipper with multiple output 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices. Definition 4

An (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain is a bus graph component consisting of

  1. 1.

    an (I,o1)𝐼subscript𝑜1(I,o_{1})( italic_I , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-flipper,

  2. 2.

    an (I1,o2)subscript𝐼1subscript𝑜2(I_{1},o_{2})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-flipper,

  3. 3.

    an (I2,o3)subscript𝐼2subscript𝑜3(I_{2},o_{3})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-flipper,

  4. 4.

    an (I3,O)subscript𝐼3𝑂(I_{3},O)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O )-perp,

and three additional edges (I1,o1)subscript𝐼1subscript𝑜1(I_{1},o_{1})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (I2,o2)subscript𝐼2subscript𝑜2(I_{2},o_{2})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (I3,o3)subscript𝐼3subscript𝑜3(I_{3},o_{3})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

An example embedding of an (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain is shown in Fig. 4.

Lemma 6

In any embedding Γnormal-Γ\Gammaroman_Γ of an (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain, Γ⁢(I)normal-Γ𝐼\Gamma(I)roman_Γ ( italic_I ) and Γ⁢(O)normal-Γ𝑂\Gamma(O)roman_Γ ( italic_O ) are parallel.

Proof

By repeatedly applying Lemma 4, Γ⁢(I)Γ𝐼\Gamma(I)roman_Γ ( italic_I ) is perpendicular to Γ⁢(I1)Γsubscript𝐼1\Gamma(I_{1})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), Γ⁢(I1)Γsubscript𝐼1\Gamma(I_{1})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is perpendicular to Γ⁢(I2)Γsubscript𝐼2\Gamma(I_{2})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Γ⁢(I2)Γsubscript𝐼2\Gamma(I_{2})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is perpendicular to Γ⁢(I3)Γsubscript𝐼3\Gamma(I_{3})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). By Lemma 3, Γ⁢(I3)Γsubscript𝐼3\Gamma(I_{3})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is perpendicular to Γ⁢(O)Γ𝑂\Gamma(O)roman_Γ ( italic_O ). It follows that Γ⁢(I)Γ𝐼\Gamma(I)roman_Γ ( italic_I ) is parallel to Γ⁢(O)Γ𝑂\Gamma(O)roman_Γ ( italic_O ).∎

Since every gadget is of linear size, the transformation clearly takes polynomial time. Finally, the following lemma completes the proof of Theorem 1.1.

Lemma 7

ϕ∈italic-ϕabsent\phi\initalic_ϕ ∈ NAE-3SAT if and only if G∈B⁢G⁢R𝐺𝐵𝐺𝑅G\in BGRitalic_G ∈ italic_B italic_G italic_R.

Proof

4 Applications of Proof Techniques

In this section, we look at variations of the bus graph realizability problem in which the degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is restricted. In the original bus graph realizability problem presented in Sect. 1, each 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex has a maximum degree of 4, due to the orthogonal drawing style. An analogous problem can be devised for the class of bus graphs where the 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices have maximum degrees of either 2 or 3. In what follows, we show that these variations are also NP-complete. Finally, we discuss the problem of merely deciding the orientation of buses, which also turns out to be NP-complete.

4.1 Connectors with Bounded Degree

First, consider the class of bus graphs where the 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices have maximum degree 1. These graphs are trivially realizable by simply drawing all the buses along a grid line. However, if the maximum degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is greater than or equal to 2, the problem becomes harder. Recall from the proof of Theorem 1.1 in Sect. 3 that the reduction from NAE-3SAT was done using a series of gadgets, each of which was based on the (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp. The following results follow from constructing an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp gadget for each case, and then constructing the remaining gadgets in a similar fashion.

Theorem 4.1

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete when the maximum degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 2.

Proof sketch.

If every 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex has degree 2, we may regard each 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex as an edge connecting two ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. Thus, in the following description, when we say to join two ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, we mean to create a 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex that joins the two ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. To construct the perp gadget, start with a complete graph K8subscript𝐾8K_{8}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with vertices labeled B1subscript𝐵1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B8subscript𝐵8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, create another vertex B9subscript𝐵9B_{9}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and join it with vertices B1subscript𝐵1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B7subscript𝐵7B_{7}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, create a vertex B10subscript𝐵10B_{10}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and join it to vertices B1subscript𝐵1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT through B6subscript𝐵6B_{6}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, B8subscript𝐵8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and B9subscript𝐵9B_{9}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It can be shown that the buses B8subscript𝐵8B_{8}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and B10subscript𝐵10B_{10}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be drawn perpendicularly to each other, and all other gadgets can be constructed based on this structure.111 For obvious reasons, we cannot use a single 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex to represent a clause. This can be resolved by creating a combination of perp gadgets and (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chains. ∎

Theorem 4.2

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete, when the maximum degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 3.

Our results can be summarized as follows.

Theorem 4.3

Bus Graph Realizability is NP-complete if and only if the maximum degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices in the given graph is 2, 3, or 4.

4.2 Partition by Orientation

In order to realize a given bus graph, one must decide the orientations of the buses. Since a connector can be joined to at most two horizontal buses and at most two vertical buses, all realizable bus graphs admit a bipartition of buses by orientation. As we will see shortly, even deciding whether the buses can be properly oriented is hard to compute. Note, however, that a proper bipartition by orientation does not guarantee that the graph is realizable.222 A simple counterexample can be constructed by first creating a complete graph with 9 ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices, and then placing a 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex on each edge.

We define the problem PARTITION-BY-ORIENTATION as follows:

Instance: A bipartite graph G=(ℬ,𝒞;ℰ)𝐺ℬ𝒞ℰG=(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C};\mathcal{E})italic_G = ( caligraphic_B , caligraphic_C ; caligraphic_E ) such that ∀c∈𝒞for-all𝑐𝒞\forall c\in\mathcal{C}∀ italic_c ∈ caligraphic_C, d⁢e⁢g⁢(c)≤4𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑐4deg(c)\leq 4italic_d italic_e italic_g ( italic_c ) ≤ 4.

Question: Can ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B be partitioned into two disjoint sets ℬℋsubscriptℬℋ\mathcal{B_{H}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℬ𝒱subscriptℬ𝒱\mathcal{B_{V}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that ∀c∈𝒞for-all𝑐𝒞\forall c\in\mathcal{C}∀ italic_c ∈ caligraphic_C, c𝑐citalic_c is adjacent to no more than two vertices in ℬℋsubscriptℬℋ\mathcal{B_{H}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no more than two vertices in ℬ𝒱subscriptℬ𝒱\mathcal{B_{V}}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT?

Theorem 4.4

PARTITION-BY-ORIENTATION is NP-complete.

Proof

The problem is clearly in NP, as one could guess a partition and check for its correctness in polynomial time. For the reduction, we use NAE-3SAT. Given an instance ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ of NAE-3SAT, we construct a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G as follows. First, for each variable xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, create an (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B )-perp. Vertex A𝐴Aitalic_A corresponds to xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, whereas vertex B𝐵Bitalic_B corresponds to xi¯¯subscript𝑥𝑖\overline{x_{i}}over¯ start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Then, for each clause Cq=(xi*∨xj*∨xk*)subscript𝐶𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘C_{q}=(x^{*}_{i}\vee x^{*}_{j}\vee x^{*}_{k})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), create a C𝐶Citalic_C-vertex cqsubscript𝑐𝑞c_{q}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and join it to the three literal vertices. The rest of the proof is similar to the proof of Lemma 7, and follows from Lemma 3. ∎

5 Bus Graph Realizability with Given Bus Lengths

In this section, we study a variation of bus graph realizability in which the lengths of buses are given as input (BGR+BL). We devise a new encoding scheme for the instances of this problem. The purpose of this encoding scheme will become clear shortly. Recall from the discussion in Sect. 2 that bus graphs can be regarded as hypergraphs, where each 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertex corresponds to a hyperedge. In the new encoding scheme, we assume that the problem instance is given as a list of subsets of ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B, where each subset is of cardinality at most 4. For each subset, we also encode the number of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices that are adjacent to exactly that subset of ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertices. Notice that this is a form of adjacency matrix for the hypergraph, where each entry in the matrix denotes the number of hyperedges for that particular subset of buses. In the case of hypergraphs where no multiple hyperedges are allowed, each entry in the matrix would be either 1 or 0.

Now we are ready to state and prove the main result of this section.

Theorem 5.1

BGR+BL is NP-hard. It is also NP-hard if the maximum degree of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C-vertices is 2, or if we require the buses to be parallel to each other.

Proof

The reduction is from PARTITION [14]. Let ⟨A,s⟩𝐴𝑠\langle A,s\rangle⟨ italic_A , italic_s ⟩ be an instance of PARTITION, where A𝐴Aitalic_A is a set of elements, and s:A→Z+:𝑠→𝐴superscript𝑍s:A\rightarrow Z^{+}italic_s : italic_A → italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a size function for each element. For simplicity, we assume that no element is of size 1, as we can scale the size function appropriately. We construct a bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G as follows. Create a ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of length 12⁢∑a∈As⁢(a)−112subscript𝑎𝐴𝑠𝑎1\frac{1}{2}\sum_{a\in A}s(a)-1divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_a ) - 1. Then, for each a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in Aitalic_a ∈ italic_A, create a ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B-vertex Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of length s⁢(a)−1𝑠𝑎1s(a)-1italic_s ( italic_a ) - 1. With the new encoding scheme, this transformation can be done in polynomial time.

Suppose ⟨A,s⟩∈𝐴𝑠absent\langle A,s\rangle\in⟨ italic_A , italic_s ⟩ ∈ PARTITION. First, lay out the bus B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT horizontally along the x𝑥xitalic_x-axis. Conversely, suppose G𝐺Gitalic_G is a yes-instance of BGR+BL. Take an embedding of G𝐺Gitalic_G, and assume without loss of generality that B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is drawn horizontally. Then, each bus Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be laid out either completely above B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, or completely below B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This means either (1) some Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn on the same grid line as B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, or (2) some Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn vertically, where one endpoint of Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is above B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the other endpoint is below B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. No connector can connect p𝑝pitalic_p with B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since every edge must connect to a bus (B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in particular) perpendicularly. This is a contradiction because each grid point along the bus Basubscript𝐵𝑎B_{a}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must connect to B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT via a connector.

This implies that the number of grid points along the buses drawn above B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT equals the number of grid points along B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Similarly, the number of grid points along the buses drawn below B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT equals the number of grid points along B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, we have a subset A′⊂Asuperscript𝐴′𝐴A^{\prime}\subset Aitalic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ italic_A, where A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the set of elements that correspond to the buses drawn above B*superscript𝐵B^{*}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and this is a valid partition. ∎

6 Concluding Remarks and Open Problems

Although bus graph realizability is an NP-complete problem in general, some special classes of graphs admit polynomial time solutions. For example, if the given bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G is a tree, it is simple to devise an algorithm to produce a realization of G𝐺Gitalic_G, and hence G𝐺Gitalic_G always admits a bus graph embedding. However, what other classes of graphs admit polynomial time recognition algorithms for realizable bus graphs is an unexplored question.

As a consequence of the hardness results of this paper, one may search for approximate solutions to the problems. It is unclear, however, what optimization criteria would be used. With applications in VLSI in mind, one may wish to lay out all the buses first, and then maximize the connectivity by maximizing the number of connectors realized in the layout.

Appendix: Necessity Proof for Lemma 7

In this section, a full proof for the necessity of the Lemma 7 is given. Let ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ denote a boolean formula for NAE-3SAT, consisting of n𝑛nitalic_n variables and m𝑚mitalic_m clauses, and let σ:X→{T,F}:𝜎→𝑋𝑇𝐹\sigma:X\rightarrow\{T,F\}italic_σ : italic_X → { italic_T , italic_F } be a satisfying truth assignment for ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ. Given ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, our goal is to show that the bus graph G𝐺Gitalic_G, constructed from the transformation shown in Sect. 3.2, is realizable. We first describe how each gadget, as introduced in Sect. 3.1, can be embedded within a bounding box of predefined size. Then, the overall embedding of G𝐺Gitalic_G is presented by explicitly giving coordinates for each gadget bounding box. Finally, we show that the so-described embedding of G𝐺Gitalic_G is a legal layout of a bus graph, which completes the proof. For simplicity, we often refer to a bounding box as an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times nitalic_n × italic_n subgrid, which is a square of size (n−1)×(n−1)𝑛1𝑛1(n-1)\times(n-1)( italic_n - 1 ) × ( italic_n - 1 ), with n𝑛nitalic_n grid points along each side.

A. Embedding of Gadgets

Note that the coordinates used in this section are relative to each corresponding gadget only.

6.0.2 Perps and Flippers.

We embed a perp within an 9×9999\times 99 × 9 subgrid, as shown in Fig. 1. In the case of the (I3,O)subscript𝐼3𝑂(I_{3},O)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O )-perp inside an (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chain, its incoming edge is connected to the grid point at the center of the bus Γ⁢(I3)Γsubscript𝐼3\Gamma(I_{3})roman_Γ ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). See Fig. 4 for an example. Similarly, a flipper is embedded in a 9×9999\times 99 × 9 subgrid, and the incoming and outgoing edges are drawn so that they lie along the same grid line as the center grid point of the subgrid. See Fig. 3 for an illustration of the embedding.

C. Correctness of the Embedding

In this section, we show that the embedding of G𝐺Gitalic_G is a legal layout. To do this, we refer back to the four properties stated in the problem definition in Sect. 1. The first two properties hold trivially by construction. Hence, it suffices to show that the other two properties hold.

Proof

We check if the properties hold as we lay out each gadget. By construction, the embedding of each individual gadget is legal. So first lay out the variable boxes and clause boxes. The embedding of these boxes together is legal, since no two boxes overlap. Now, lay out the (I,O)𝐼𝑂(I,O)( italic_I , italic_O )-chains and see if the two properties still hold.

(Property 3.) We say an edge passes through a gadget if the embedded edge enters and exits the bounding box of the gadget. (Property 4.) We say two gadgets intersect if the bounding boxes of the two embedded gadgets intersect. Since each bus or connector is embedded within some gadget, if no two gadgets intersect then no buses or connectors may intersect. We categorize the gadgets into 5 types as follows.
